docs.lead_paragraph: Even before the Clinton Administration and Congress settle on the politically delicate steps needed to insure Social Security's long-term health, the strong economy has bolstered the retirement system's financial condition, the Government reported today. The Administration said the latest review of Social Security's books showed that higher-than-expected economic growth, low inflation and low unemployment had combined to extend the retirement system's solvency by three years, to 2032, from the date projected last year.

headline.main: Surging Economy Is Lifting Social Security, U.S. Finds

docs.abstract: Social Security trustees report higher-than-expected economic growth, low inflation and low unemployment have combined to extend Social Security's solvency by three years, to 2032; Pres Clinton hails news but says steps are still needed to bolster system; trustees report Medicare will remain financially sound until 2008, reflecting changes in Medicare's hospital insurance program; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Even before the Clinton Administration and Congress settle on the politically delicate steps needed to insure Social Security's long-term health, the strong economy has bolstered the retirement system's financial condition, the Government reported...
